awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Controlling Arylene Ethynylene Structure and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists can impart desirable properties, such as flexibility or the ability to conduct electricity, into materials through strategic design of the chemical components that make up the materials. One of the most important considerations in this endeavor is how the chemical components within a material interact with each other. The Bowling and Speetzen research groups at the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point (UWSP) collaborate with the Bosch group at the Missouri State University to study new organic compounds designed that increase understanding of important chemical interactions in materials.  Their research also explores new strategies for achieving desirable properties. Calculations from the Speetzen research group not only help with interpretation of experimental results but also inform the design of new chemical structures. The strategies developed in these studies provide a foundation for creating materials that have enhanced electron transport capabilities, potentially leading to improved next-generation devices, such as thin-film transistors or light-emitting diodes. The undergraduate students responsible for this research gain expertise synthesizing, purifying, and characterizing novel chemical structures.  They also gain insight into how fundamental chemical forces can be used to develop commercially useful materials. This combination of hands-on skills and chemical perspective prepares them well for careers in chemical industry or further studies in graduate school. 

The molecules targeted in this collaborative study are classified as arylene ethynylenes (AEs) as they have alternating alkynes and aromatic rings throughout. AEs are attractive not only for their conjugation and rigidity, but also because the relatively free rotation around the single bonds linking alkynes and aromatic rings provides access to an array of unique intramolecular attractions or supramolecular structures. Molecules designed in the Bowling group laboratories utilize the tendency of rigid AE structures to stack in predictable arrangements in order to study charge transfer (CT) between electron-rich and electron-poor aromatic rings. Similar CT behavior is studied by installing electron-rich and electron-poor units within a single AE compound. Rotation of the AE backbone offers access to both CT-favorable and CT-unfavorable conformations, which provides insight into using CT as an organizational driving force and an opportunity for development of molecular switches. This project also seeks to realize the potential for AEs to function in supramolecular structures through the transition metal coordination of a hexagonal AE ligand and by using pnictogen bonding to assemble supramolecular pyramids or bipyramids that have the potential to serve as cages for specific guest molecules.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
How molecules are arranged within a material is critical to the material’s function. The ability to control how molecules arrange gives scientists the opportunity to manipulate and design new functionality in a material, an important step in pushing technological boundaries. This kind of design is a non-trivial venture, however, as there are many interconnected variables that control how molecules arrange themselves. The NSF-funded (CHE-1903581, CHE-1903593) collaboration between chemists at the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point (UWSP) and Missouri State University (MSU) has led to significant advances in controlling how molecules arrange in solution and in the solid state. Over the course of these awards, the primary investigators and their students have designed and generated dozens of novel arylene ethynylenes—a class of molecules desirable for myriad electronic applications—in order to enhance and better understand the tools available for controlling how molecules arrange themselves within a material.

 

The work has been performed by 30 students (26 undergraduates, 4 Masters) over four years in laboratories at UWSP and MSU. Not only did these students perform the chemical reactions necessary to generate the novel organic compounds required for these studies, but they also developed and optimized methods to purify these compounds for further reaction or for analytical study. Students were also responsible for identifying and characterizing these compounds on a daily basis via 1H and 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopies. Once products were purified and their identities confirmed, students further studied their properties via techniques such as UV-vis spectroscopy or X-ray crystallography.

 

One of the most significant advances associated with this award was the development of an efficient and reliable route to solid state molecular rotors. A solid state molecular rotor has a component, a rotator, that can spin around an axis unperturbed by the atoms or molecules that surround them. This is unusual behavior given that one hallmark of solid materials is that the atoms and molecules within them are essentially frozen in place. Having components that are able to spin on an axis in solid materials provides an avenue for the development of molecular scale memory devices or switches. The strategy developed in our laboratories provides facile access to molecular rotors, greatly simplifying the process for generating compounds of this type.

 

A second significant advance was the utilization of relatively unconventional intermolecular forces to organize molecules in the solid state. Forces such as halogen bonding, pnictogen bonding, and C-H hydrogen bonding are not often used in material design because they can be unpredictable and sometimes weak relative to other forces that are present. By incorporating appropriate features onto rigid, geometrically stable frameworks, methods have been developed to use these forces to help organize molecules in a predictable, reproducible way. These organizational strategies were used to enhance electronic communication between neighboring molecules via through-space charge transfer, a phenomenon gaining increasing interest due its importance in photocatalysis, among other things.

 

Beyond the scientific impact of the work, undergraduate and Masters students working on these projects have gained invaluable hands-on training that prepares them to excel in scientific industry or graduate study. To date, 10 of the 30 students who have worked on these projects have chosen to continue their scientific education and training in chemistry, biochemistry, or engineering graduate programs. Several of the nine students who have yet to graduate are also choosing this path. The progress of students working on these projects, along with their mentor PIs and other collaborators, has been communicated in 13 peer-reviewed journal articles featuring 13 different student coauthors. Several student and faculty presentations at local and national meetings have also featured this work.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2023
Modified by: Eric Bosch
